question: What landform forms where a river slows at its mouth, fans out, and deposits sediment?

content.source_1: Alluvial fans form where steep, confined flows exit onto a low-gradient plain without entering standing water; the sudden loss of confinement and velocity causes sediment to spread out in a cone- or fan-shaped deposit at the base of the slope.
content.source_2: On hillsides during storms, runoff in gullies commonly decelerates and spreads across the footslope or valley floor, leaving a small fan-shaped apron of debrisâ€”an observable analog of an alluvial fan.
content.source_3: Deltas develop where a stream or river enters a standing body of water (lake or sea); the flow slows sharply at the mouth, depositing sediment in lobate or fan-shaped bodies that prograde from the shoreline.
content.source_4: Some foothill settings include closed basins or ephemeral ponds that fill during storms; when gully flows enter these temporary standing waters, they can build small deltas along the pond margin.
content.source_5: Both alluvial fans and deltas show proximal-to-distal sorting, with coarser material near the entry point and finer material spread farther out, reflecting deceleration and flow expansion.
content.source_6: The environmental discriminator is the receiving setting: alluvial fans are subaerial landforms at slope bases, whereas deltas are shoreline deposits formed where streams enter standing water; both can appear fan-shaped due to flow spreading.
